ago now we see evidence they use tools
in all kinds of different contexts you
know tools to get at Food tools to
attract other Ms you know tools to kind
of sponge off seeds and climb up trees
tools for all kinds of different things
um they even seem in some cases to have
tool kits so kits of tools that they'll
use for one particular function where
they'll use different parts of the same
tool and a multiple different tools um
and this really impresses us but this is
kind of the limit of it you there's
nothing like the kinds of complex tools
uh or technologies that we see uh in

deucing to use tools you know ones that
are relatively complicated for other
species but they don't seem to have

cumula evolution of different tool
cultures that in some sense take on a

individuals are contributing to this the
kinds of designs that we come up with in

improved on by the other generation
again you see little bits of this but
nothing at the scale that we have in our
own
species it's still a big puzzle as to
why we're the only species that has
cumulative technology in the way that we
do
uh one answer that seems to be coming up
uh might have to do with the way that
humans imitate uh other individuals uh
so there was uh recently a study by Andy
whiten and his colleagues trying to look
at the ways that human children imitate
uh a person acting on a tool versus the
way that chimpanzees imitate and so the
experiment W like this uh both children
and chimpanzees were given a little
puzzle box uh it was opaque they
couldn't see how it worked but they get
to watch a human demonstrator open it up
and theep to open it up were of two
parts first it involved kind of tapping
the puzzle box in the top in this sort
of way and then it involves opening a
door and taking out a treat so both kids
and chimpanzees after seeing this can
follow the experiment or perfectly so
they do the tapping part open the door
get the treat now you do the same search
setup except instead of the Box being
opaque it's now transparent and it's
obvious to both the child the child
subjects and the chimpanzees that the
whole tapping part at the top is just
bogus like the tapping doesn't actually
go anywhere it's like kind of a false
top um so you could see as you're
watching a person do this that you don't
need to do this all you have to do is
open the door when you give this puzzle
to chimpanzees they do what you might
expect to be the smart maneuver they
just kind of cut to the Chase and open
the door and take the treat when you do
this with human children however what
you find surprisingly and perhaps
embarrassingly for our species is that
the human children slavishly imitate the
person they see so even though they can
clearly see that this you know poking in
the top is a stupid gesture they do it
anyway um what it seems like is that
humans really are paralyzed by watching
the actions of others actually seems to
change our causal intuitions about how
different objects work this is bad when
people do really stupid things on boxes
and open them the wrong way but it's
great for the cumulative evolution of
Technology because it means you don't
have to know the physics or the the
causal aspects of how something works
you just basically follow somebody's
actions do that yourself and then you
can pass on these kinds of cultures to
the Next Generation Um so in some SS the
fact that chimpanzees don't rely on
social information as much as they seem
to rely on physics actually means they
might not learn about Technologies in
the same fast way that humans do because
if you think about the kinds of
technologies that we deal with you know
they're often so physically complex that
we can't explain them you know I use my
iPhone every day but I have no idea how
it works you know I slide the little bar
and that's what I understand um but for
chimpanzees all the Technologies they
work have physics that are really
obvious so affordances that they could
